content: <collection xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/MARC21/slim">    <dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:invenio="http://invenio-software.org/elements/1.0" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd"><dc:identifier>doi:10.5281/zenodo.15640</dc:identifier><dc:creator>Zipser, Florian</dc:creator><dc:creator>Frank, Mario</dc:creator><dc:creator>Schmolling, Jakob</dc:creator><dc:title>Merging data, the essence of creation of multi-layer corpora</dc:title><dc:subject>cc-by</dc:subject><dc:description><p>The last couple of years have shown an increasing number of multi layer corpora. Such<br /> corpora allow the analysis of phenomena spreading through multiple annotation layers, for<br /> example corpora like TueBaDZ (see: http://www.sfs.uni-tuebingen.de/ascl/ressourcen/corpora/tueba-dz.html), PCC (see: http://www.ling.uni-potsdam.de/acl-lab/Forsch/pcc/pcc.html), FALKO (see: https://u.hu-berlin.de/falko) and many other corpora contain annotations on syntactical, rhetorical, information structural and other layers. Often, annotations were created manually, or semi-automatically with different tools like EXMARaLDA (see: http://www.exmaralda.org/), TreeTagger (see: http://www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/tools/TreeTagger/) and MMAX2 (see: http://mmax2.sourceforge.net/).<br /> These tools are powerful and usable but unfortunately only provide a minimum of<br /> interoperability, which impedes the creation of multi layer corpora. Thus, multiple layers of<br /> such corpora often had to be merged by hand or by very proprietary scripts implemented for<br /> just one use case and therefore could not be reused for other corpora easily.<br /> With this poster we present a tool which merges several layers of annotations into a single<br /> multi layer corpus. When creating a multi layer corpus, several analyses base on the same<br /> primary data and often also on the same tokenization.<br /> We started merging the data on the tokenization level and traversed bottom up, to merge even<br /> higher levels of annotation. This concept is implemented in a module for the converter<br /> framework Pepper (see: https://u.hu-berlin.de/saltnpepper) with use of the common meta-<br /> model Salt. By using Pepper, the merging module is able to handle all formats which can be<br /> imported by a Pepper module. Multi layered corpora then can be mapped into a multilayer<br /> formats like PAULA (Chiarcos et al. 2008), GrAF (Ide &amp; Suderman 2007) or can be imported<br /> into ANNIS.</p></dc:description><dc:publisher/><dc:date>2014-03-06</dc:date><dc:source>http://zenodo.org/record/15640</dc:source><dc:doi>10.5281/zenodo.15640</dc:doi><dc:identifier>http://zenodo.org/record/15640</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>oai:zenodo.org:15640</dc:identifier></dc:dc>   </collection>
